newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS- NOV 20.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS- NOV 20.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek financial press:
KATHIMERINI

--The money markets are up in arms as the government prepares to tax interbank deals. Bankers have expressed fears that there may be a significant increase in interest rates in the course of the day and that if the government persists in the tax there will be certain rises in interest rates.

--The Capital Market Commission yesterday moves beyond the confidentiality of client-broker relations, asking for all 65 firms to present analytical details of all transactions for clients to international overseers Ernst & Young.
--A decision on the increase in the share capital of Ergo Bank is postponed to mid-December.
--The contract for the maintenance and upgrading of the Promahonas border post - estimated at 127 million drachmas - will be bid tomorrow.
--Gross profits since the beginning of the year at the country's five private and one state-run casinos have passed the 50 billion drachma mark. Punters have played over 200 billion drachmas.
IMERISIA
--Central questions on how the taxation of the interbank market deals will be conducted remain unanswered by the government. The uncertainty has created tension in banks and among investors.
--Brokers yesterday expressed concern about the confidentiality of financial transactions after the Capital Market Commission sanctioned the in-depth investigation of all bourse members.
--The 1997 budget foresees 996 billion drachma more in taxes with further revenues coming from the abolition of tax breaks, readjusted wealth indicators and taxation of state titles.
--Forecast GDP is 3.3 percent, higher than any other European Union country, and will be achieved with increased private and public investments.
--The budget sets the ambitious inflation target of 4.5 percent by the end of 1997.
--The hard drachma policy will continue, fluctuations of the currency will be minimal and will lead by the end of 1997 to a stable parity with the Ecu.
KERDOS

--National Economy Minister Yannos Papandoniou gives Greece a sneak preview of the budget, immediately after yesterday's cabinet meeting. The figures show that this year's budget has seen delayed revenues and overspending: the 1997 budget hopes to garner 1.1 trillion in taxes.
--A storm of protest has greeted the government's intention to tax interbank transactions: the market freezes on the news and 300 million dollars in forex outflows are registered.
--Delta Securities' shares and documents have been confiscated by an Athens prosecutor and now lie in the National Bank of Greece safe.
EXPRESS
--Prime Minister Costas Simitis asks for all to support the budget but the opposition sees no reason to. Plans for inflation are overly-ambitious and incomes policy overly tight.
NAFTEMBORIKI
--Business circles say the new budget restricts potential for growth and that it is geared to collect revenues.

--The competition commission yesterday imposed its first severe fine since becoming an independent authority, banning the concentration of the Kamari and Vosinaki firms. --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
